article: My father was a self-taught mandolin player. He was one of the best string instrument players in our town. He could not _ music, but if he heard a tune a few times, he could play it. I loved to sing, but I never learned how to _ the mandolin. This is something I _ to this day. Dad loved to play the mandolin for his _ as he knew we enjoyed singing, and hearing him play. He was always there, _ his time and efforts to see that his family had enough in their life. I had to mature into a man and have children of my own _ I realized how much he had sacrificed. _ played the mandolin like my father. He could _ your soul with the tones. He seemed to shine when he was playing. You could see his _ in his ability to play so well for his family. One day, he was involved in an _ .On this particular day, Dad got the first finger of his left hand _ by the machine. The doctor who operated on the finger could not _ it, which did affect his _ to play the mandolin. After the accident, Dad felt that he could not play _ .When I came home and asked him to play, he would make _ for why he couldn't play. In August of 1993 my father was diagnosed with _ lung cancer. About a week before his death, we asked Dad if he would play the mandolin for us. He said _ .He knew it would probably be the last time he could play for us. When I looked around, there was not a _ eye in the family. We saw before us a quiet man with an inner _ Dad was always doing something he had done all his life _ .
